msContents.summary: A 17th-18th century manuscript of the Ratnamālāvadāna, a collection of avadānas belonging to the cycle of king Aśoka and the monk Upagupta. The title given in the manuscript is Avadānaratnamālā (see the running marginal title under Marginalia). On the inside of the front cover, a note written in Nepālākṣarā bears the date 903 in Nepāla Saṃvat, corresponding to 1783 CE. This date does not necessarily refer to the writing date of the manuscript, it might have been added by one of the owners, a certain Jayendraka (śrī jayendrakasyedaṃ pustakaṃ saṃvat 903). This manuscript has not been used by Takahata for his editio princeps.

supportDesc.foliation: Nepālākṣarā numerals, mid-right margin, verso. Folio 24 is foliated also as 22 on the recto, and folio 25 is mistakenly numbered as 24; the foliation then follows this wrong numbering. For this reason, all references to folios are provided first with the original foliation, then with the modern continuous foliation in Arabic numerals (for instance, folio 33v6 [original foliation] = 34v6 [reference foliation]).

Nepālākṣarā numerals, top left margin, verso, starting from folio 25 (again mistakenly numbered as 24); this second foliation too follows the wrong numbering. Folio 82v = 83v is numbered as 81 (in this foliation only).
Arabic numerals, top right margin, verso (reference foliation).
supportDesc.condition: Incomplete: folios 13 and 63 are missing (with lacunae corresponding to Snātāvadāna 2.35bcd-2.39abc in Takahata's edition, which however contains a slightly different text; the Devatāparipṛcchāsūtra ended on folio 63); the manuscript ends abruptly on folio 116v7 (= 117v7) with the beginning of the Daśaśirāvadāna; good condition.

layout.p: 6-8 lines per page, approximately 50-60 akṣaras per line.
Double marginal writing frame lines; ruling at the beginning and end (roughly corresponding to the folios written by the first and third hands).
